lines.text: Ohhhh fuuudge!

[narrating]
Only I didn't say "Fudge." I said THE word, the big one, the queen-mother of dirty words, the "F-dash-dash-dash" word!

[stunned]
*What* did you say?
Uh, um...
That's... what I thought you said. Get in the car. Go on!

[narrating]
It was all over - I was dead. What would it be? The guillotine? Hanging? The chair? The rack? The Chinese water torture? Hmmph. Mere child's play compared to what surely awaited me.

[narrating]
Only one thing in the world could've dragged me away from the soft glow of electric sex gleaming in the window.
He looks like a deranged Easter Bunny.
He does not!
He does too, he looks like a pink nightmare!
I want an official Red Ryder, carbine action, two-hundred shot range model air rifle!
No, you'll shoot your eye out.
Are you kidding? Stick my tongue to that stupid pole? That's dumb!
That's 'cause you know it'll stick!
You're full of it!
Oh yeah?
Yeah!
Well I double-DOG-dare ya!

[narrating]
NOW it was serious. A double-dog-dare. What else was there but a "triple dare you"? And then, the coup de grace of all dares, the sinister triple-dog-dare.
I TRIPLE-dog-dare ya!

[narrating]
Schwartz created a slight breach of etiquette by skipping the triple dare and going right for the throat!
[in a Chinese restaurant]

[singing]
Deck the harrs with boughs of horry, fa ra ra ra ra, ra ra ra ra.
No, no, not 'ra ra ra ra', 'la la la la'! Try again.
Deck the harrs with boughs of horry, fa ra ra ra ra, ra ra ra ra.
No, no! Sing something else.
Jingre bers, jingre bers, jingre arr the way. Oh what fun it is to ride in a one-horse open sreigh!
[Mr. Parker reads a side of the box with the prize that he won]
Aaah! "Fra-GEE-leh!" It must be Italian!
Uh, I think that says FRAGILE, honey.
Huh? Oh, yeah.
[nods in agreement]
Meatloaf, smeatloaf, double-beatloaf. I hate meatloaf.
All right, I'll get that kid to eat. Where's my screw driver and my plumber's helper? I'll open up his mouth and I'll shove it in.

[narrating]
The old man stood there, quivering with fury, stammering as he tried to come up with a real crusher. All he got out was...
Naddafinga!
[last lines]

[narrating]
Next to me in the blackness lay my oiled blue steel beauty. The greatest Christmas gift I had ever received, or would ever receive. Gradually, I drifted off to sleep, pranging ducks on the wing and getting off spectacular hip shots.
What is the name of the Lone Ranger's nephew's horse?
Ah... Victor! His name is Victor.
How the hell did you know that?
Everybody knows that!

[narrating, after BB gun shot bounces off target and hits his face]
Oh my god, I shot my eye out!

[narrating]
Some men are Baptists, others Catholics; my father was an Oldsmobile man.
That son of a bitch would freeze up in the middle of summer on the equator!
Little pitchers!
Thanks... hold it!
[the furnace conks out]
It's a clinker! That blasted stupid furnace dadgummit!
[he walks down a few stairs and falls the rest of the way down]
Damn skates!
[coughing]
Oh, for cripes sake, open up the damper will ya? Who the hell turned it all the way down? AGAIN! Oh, blast it!

[narrating]
In the heat of battle my father wove a tapestry of obscenities that as far as we know is still hanging in space over Lake Michigan.
Aunt Clara had for years labored under the delusion that I was not only perpetually 4 years old, but also a girl.

[narrating]
Meanwhile, I struggled for exactly the right BB gun hint. It had to be firm, but subtle.
Flick says he saw some grizzly bears near Pulaski's candy store!
[everyone stares at Ralphie]

[narrating]
They looked at me as if I had lobsters crawling out of my ears.

[narrating about diving with his brother into the gifts under the Christmas tree]
We plunged into the cornucopia quivering with desire and the ecstasy of unbridled avarice.
Didn't I get a tie this year?
[overdressed for winter]
I can't put my arms down!
Well... put your arms down when you get to school.

[Mr. Parker's beloved leg lamp is broken]
Get the glue.
We're out of glue.
You used up all the glue on purpose!
All right. Now, are you ready to tell me where you heard that word?

[narrating]
Now, I had heard that word at least ten times a day from my old man. He worked in profanity the way other artists might work in oils or clay. It was his true medium; a master. But, I chickened out and said the first name that came to mind.
Schwartz!

[unveiling his major award]
Would you look at that? Would you look at THAT?
What is it?
It's a leg!
But what is it?
Well, it's... A leg, you know, like a statue.
Statue?
Yeah, statue.
Yeah, statue.
Ralphie!

[narrating]
My mother was trying to insinuate herself between us and the statue.
"A Red Ryder BB gun with a compass in the stock, and this thing which tells time". Poetry. Sheer poetry, Ralph! An A+!

[gets on the phone]
Hello, Mrs. Schwartz? Yes, I'm fine. Uh, Mrs. Schwartz, do you know what Ralph just said?
[Mrs. Schwartz's speech is inaudible]
No, he said...
[whispers it close to the receiver]

[in a hysterical tone]
NO, NOT THAT!
Yes, that! Do you know where he heard it?
Probably from his father.
No! He heard it from your son!

[screams hysterically]
WHAT! WHAT! WHAAAAAAT!
[footsteps are heard followed by screaming and spanking]

[crying]
Ah, no! What did I do, Ma? What, I didn't do nothing! AAAAUUUUGGGGHHH!
[Ralphie's mom hangs up the phone]

[narrating]
Another shot of mysterious, inexorable, official justice.
[after cracking a secret code]

[Reading it]
Be sure to drink your Ovaltine. Ovaltine? A crummy commercial? Son of a bitch!
Heh, I was just kidding, even though Schwartz is getting one. I guess I'd just like some Tinker Toys.

[narrating]
I couldn't believe my own ears. Tinker Toys? She'd never buy it.
Randy? What's wrong? Whatcha cryin' for?
Daddy's gonna kill Ralphie!
No he's not...
Yes he is!
No, I promise, Daddy is not going to kill Ralphie!
00, he can kiss my foot. Ho ho ho.

[Reading Telegram and doing a little jig]
Tonight! Tonight! It's coming Tonight! Tonight! Tonight! Tonight! Hot Damn, Tonight!

[narrating]
The snap of a few sparks, a quick whiff of ozone, and the lamp blazed forth in unparalleled glory.
Oh, look at that! Will you look at that? Isn't that glorious? It's... it's... it's indescribably beautiful! It reminds me of the Fourth of July!
Dadgummit! Blow out!
[on the highway, the car has gotten a flat tire]
Ah ha!
[excitedly gets out of the car]
Not again.
Four minutes. Time me.

[narrating]
Actually the Old Man loved it. He had always pictured himself in the pits of the Indianapolis Speedway in the 500. My old man's spare tires were actually only tires in the academic sense. They were round, they had once been made of rubber.

[narrating]
Oh, life is like that. Sometimes, at the height of our revelries, when our joy is at it's zenith, when all is most right with the world, the most unthinkable disasters decend upon us.
Ralphie, you're lucky it didn't cut your eye! Those icicles have been known to kill people.
Randy, how do the little piggies go?
[oinks like a pig]
That's right. Oink, oink! Now show me how the piggies eat.
[points to his plate]
This is your trough. Show me how the piggies eat. Be a good boy. Show mommy how the piggies eat.
[plunges face into mashed potatoes, oinks, eats, and laughs]

[laughs]
Mommy's little piggie!

Now I know that some of you put Flick up to this, but he has refused to say who. But those who did it know their blame, and I'm sure that the guilt you feel is far worse than any punishment you might receive. Now, don't you feel terrible? Don't you feel remorse for what you have done? Well, that's all I'm going to say about poor Flick.

[narrating]
Adults loved to say things like that but kids knew better. We knew darn well it was always better not to get caught.

[narrating]
My father worked in profanity the way other artists might work in oils or clay. It was his true medium, a master.
It's a Major Award!
A Major Award? Shucks, I wouldn't know that. It looks like a lamp.
It is a lamp, you nincompoop, but it's a Major Award. I won it!
Damn, hell, you say won it?
Yeah, mind power, Swede; mind power.
[Ralphie is visiting Santa at the department store, only he can't remember what he wanted]
How about a nice football?

[narrating]
Football? Football? What's a football? With unconscious will my voice squeaked out 'football'.
Okay, get him out of here.

[narrating]
A football? Oh no, what was I doing? Wake up, Stupid! Wake up!

[Ralphie is shoved down the slide, but he stops himself and climbs back up]
No! No! I want an Official Red Ryder Carbine-Action Two-Hundred-Shot Range Model Air Rifle!
You'll shoot your eye out, kid.

[narrating]
My little brother had not eaten voluntarily in over three years.

[Watching in horror as the Bumpus hounds flee after devouring the Christmas turkey]
Sons of bitches! Bumpuses!

[narrating]
Over the years I got to be quite a connoisseur of soap. My personal preference was for Lux, but I found Palmolive had a nice, piquant after-dinner flavor - heady, but with just a touch of mellow smoothness. Life Buoy, on the other hand...
YECCHH!
I like The Wizard of Oz. I like the Tin Man.

[narrating]
The line waiting to see Santa Claus stretched all the way back to Terre Haute. And I was at the end of it.
You mundane noodle!

[narrating]
My kid brother looked like a tick about to pop!
Mom, this is just the same dumb old parade as last year.
Ralphie, will you please calm down?
Mom!
Hush!
SHUT UP, Ralphie!

[narrating]
Strange. Even something as momentous as the Scut Farkus affair, which it came to be known, was pushed out of my mind as I struggled to come up with a way out of the impenetrable BB gun web, in which my mother had me trapped.
Santa. Yeah, I'll ask Santa.

[narrating]
Of course. Santa. The big man. The head honcho. The connection. Ha, my mother had slipped up this time.

[narrating, after Mother breaks the Old Man's Major Award, and he is unsuccessful at repairing it]
With as much dignity as he could muster, the Old Man gathered up the sad remains of his shattered major award. Later that night, alone in the backyard, he buried it next to the garage. Now I could never be sure, but I thought that I heard the sound of "Taps" being played, gently.
Hey Dad! I'll bet you'll never guess what I got you for Christmas.
A new furnace.
Ha ha! That's a good one, Dad!
[Randy laughs]
Get in the car. Get in the car.
[Mother runs back inside]
If we don't hurry, we're gonna miss all the good trees!

[to the kids]
Go on, go on.

[narrating, as Mother switches off the leg lamp]
My mother was about to make another brilliant maneuver in the legendary battle of the lamp. The epic struggle which follows lives in the folklore of Cleveland Street to this very day.
Don't want to waste electricity.

[mockingly]
"Don't want to waste electricity."
[Describing a "reaction" to an encounter with the bullies]

[narrating]
Randy lay there like a slug! It was his only defense!

[narrating]
I have since heard of people under extreme duress speaking in strange tongues. I became conscious that a steady torrent of obscenities and swearing of all kinds was pouring out of me as I screamed.

[narrating]
Grover Dill! Farkus's crummy little toadie. Mean! Rotten! His lips curled over his green teeth.
Scut Farkus!

[narrating]
Scut Farkus! What a rotten name! We were trapped. There he stood, between us and the alley. Scut Farkus staring out at us with his yellow eyes. He had yellow eyes! So, help me, God! Yellow eyes!

[shouting]
Don't anybody move! Hold it right there! The fuse is out.
[marveling at a Christmas gift he just opened]
A can of Simoniz!
I like Santa.
Yeah.

[narrating]
Let's face it, most of us are scoffers. But moments before zero hour, it did not pay to take chances.
So what else happened today?
Oh, nothing much. Ralphie had a fight?
A fight? What kind of a fight?
[Looks at Ralphie]
Oh, you know how boys are. I gave him a talking to...
[Looks at the newspaper]
Uh I see that the Bears are playing Green Bay on Sunday.
What? Oh yeah! Zudock's got tickets I wish I had. Aw well, let him freeze his keister off out there.
Where's Flick? Has anyone seen Flick?

[narrating as Ralphie feigns ignorance]
Flick? Flick who?

[after Mother "accidentally" breaks the Old Man's leg lamp]
Don't you touch that! You were always jealous of this lamp.
Jealous of a plastic...
Jealous! Jealous because I WON.
That's ridiculous. Jealous. Jealous of WHAT? That is... the ugliest lamp I have ever seen in my entire LIFE!

[narrating]
Now it was out.
This isn't one of those trees where all the needles falls off, is it?
No, that's them balsams.
Is this another one of your silly puzzles?
Yeah, another one of my silly puzzles. This one could be worth FIFTY THOUSAND BUCKS.
What is it this time?
Name the great characters in American literature.
Victor? The Lone Ranger's nephew's horse?

[narrating]
There has never been a kid who didn't believe vaguely but incessantly that he would be stricken blind before he reached 21, and then they'd be sorry.

[in his fantasy, Ralphie explains the cause of his blindness]
It... It 'twas... soap poisoning!

[Giving his teacher a fruit basket instead of just an apple]
I thought you might like something different.
Yes, clearly, a little bribe never hurts.

[chuckling]
Ho, ho, but no matter. Christmas was on its way. Lovely, glorious, beautiful Christmas, upon which the entire kid year revolved.
First-nighters, packed earmuff-to-earmuff, jostled in wonderment before a golden, tinkling display of mechanized, electronic joy!
Mothers know nothing about creeping marauders burrowing through the snow toward the kitchen where only you and you alone stand between your tiny, huddled family and insensate evil.
Immediately, my feet began to sweat as those two fluffy little bunnies with a blue button eye stared sappily up at me.
Come down so I can see you better.
I just hope Flick would never spot them as a word of this humiliation could make easier in life at Warren G. Harding School a variatable Hell.
You filty sicken hook-aid! Oh, smelly wok buster! Grout shell fratten house stickle fifer! You bladder puss nut grafter! Dorton hoper...
What happened next was a family controversy for years.
You wart mundane noodle! You shotten shifter paskabah! You snort tonguer! Lame monger snaffa shell cocker!
[the sound of the lamp breaking is heard]

[Going inside the house after the Bumpus hounds devoured the Christmas turkey]
All right! Everybody upstairs! Get dressed! We are going out... to eat!

[In the Chinese restaurant, the waiter brings out the cooked duck, which still has its head on; Mrs. Parker is laughing]
Yes, it's a beautiful duck. It really is. But you see... it's smiling at me.
[He lifts the head of the duck]
Ooohh!
[He chops off the duck's head. Mrs. Parker and the kids are laughing]
That Christmas would live in our memories as the year we were introduced to Chinese turkey.

[Firemen come to pull Flick off pole]
Holy cow, it's the fire department!
Oh no...

[policemen come]
Wow, it's the cops!
It could be a bowling alley!
How are they going to deliver a bowling alley here tonight?
They'll send the deed for cripesake. I didn't expect them to send a whole damn bowling alley.
My father's spare tires were only tires on the academic sense. They were round,and had once been made of rubber.
COME ON, KID!
[pulls Ralphie]
COME ON!
HO! HO HO!
[spins Ralphie around]
HOOOO... HOOO... HOO... And what's your name little boy?
Hey, kid! HURRY UP! THE STORE'S CLOSING!
Listen little boy, we have A LOT of people waiting here, so GET GOING!

[narrating]
Getting ready to go to school was like getting ready for extended deep-sea diving.
Hey, smart ass. I asked my old man about sticking your tongue to a flagpole in the winter, and he says that it'll freeze right to the pole, just like I told ya.
Ah, baloney. What would your old man know about anything?
He knows, because he once saw a guy stick his tongue to a railroad track on a bet, and the fire department had to come get the guy's tongue off the track, because he couldn't get it off.

[is trying to catch up]
C'mon, guys! Wait up! C'mon, guys! Wait up!
Young man. Hey, kid! Just where do you think you're going?
Going up to see Santa.
The line ENDS here. It begins THERE.
[Points to the very end of a very long line]

[narrating]
I left Flick to certain annihilation. But BB gun mania knows no loyalty.
Come on up on Santa's lap, here's a wet one. And what's your name little boy? And what do you want for Christmas, Billy? A toy truck? Get him off my lap and get my a towel.
[Billy is pushed down the slide]
Oh, I hate the smell of tapioca.

[Playing Santa]
And this is for daddy...
[Picks up a gift-wrapped bowling ball and drops it in The Old Man's Lap]
Here, from me to you.

[high-pitched]
Thanks a lot!
Randy, will you eat? There are starving people in China!
[groans and shoves spoon into his mouth]

[to Mother]
You know, Zudock just bought one of those brand new green, plastic trees.
Oh no!
Darn thing looked like it was made of green pipe cleaners. Hee hee hee hee.
It's a very nice tree.

[quickly]
I'll thrown in some rope and tie it to your car for you.
You got a deal.
Deal.

[narrating]
The heavenly aroma still hung in the house. But it was gone, all gone! No turkey! No turkey sandwiches! No turkey salad! No turkey gravy! Turkey Hash! Turkey a la King! Or gallons of turkey soup! Gone, ALL GONE!
Holy smokes. Do... Do you know what this is? This is... A lamp!

[narrating]
It was indeed a lamp.
Isn't that great? What a great lamp.
I don't know...

[narrating]
The old man's eyes boggled...
Oh WOW!

[narrating]
... Overcome by art.
C+? Oh no, it CAN'T be!

[in Ralphie's fantasy, dressed as the Wicked Witch]
C+! C+! Ha ha ha ha ha ha!
Was there no end to the conspiracy of irrational prejudice against Red Ryder and his peacemaker?

[regarding the note on his report]
Oh, no! "You'll shoot your eye out!"?
Oh, no!
My mother must have gotten to Miss Shields! There could be no other explanation!

[in Ralphie's fantasy, Miss Shields is dressed as the Wicked Witch and Ralphie's mother as a jester, both chanting]
"You'll shoot your eye out! You'll shoot your eye out! Ha ha ha ha ha ha!
Was there no end to this conspiracy of irrational prejudice against Red Ryder and his peacemaker?
I slowly began to realize that i was not going to be destroyed.
Well, what have we got here, folks?
Well, we figure it's Black Bart, uh, Ralph.
Well, it's just me and my trusty old Red Ryder carbine-action, 200-shot, range model air rifle. Lucky I got a compass in the stock.

[narrating]
Honors and benefits already at the age of nine!
Downtown Hohman was preparing for this yearly baccanalia of peace on Earth and goodwill to men.
Round One was over. heh heh. Parents one, kids, zip. I can feel the Christmas noose beginning to tighten. Maybe, what happened next, was inevitable.
Ralphie, what would you like for Christmas?
Horrified, I heard myself blurt it out!
I want a Red Ryder carbine action two-hundred shot range model air rifle. Oooooooh!
No, you'll shoot your eye out.

Oh no! It was a classic, mother BB-gun block. "You'll shoot your eye out!" That deadly phrase honored many times by hundreds of mothers was not surmountable by any means known to Kid-dom, but such as my mania, my desire for a Red Ryder carbine, that I immediately began to rebuild the dike.
[Furnace makes creaking noise]
Hold it! Shhh...
[Furnace makes loud banging noises]
Aha! Aha! It's a clinkerrrr! That blasted, stupid furnace! Dadgummit!
[Mr. Parker falls down the stairs]
Damn skates!
[coughing]

Oh for cripe's sake, open up that damper, will ya? Who the hell turned it all the way down? Hawk head! Aw, blasted poop flirt rattle crap camel flirt. You blonker frattle feet sturckle frat! Of a womp sack butt ratter bottom fodder...
In the heat of battle, my father wove a tapestry of obscenity, that as far as we know is still hanging in space over Lake Michigan.
...smick melly whop walker. Drop dumb fratten house stickle fifer!
[Explaining rather sheepishly to Mother why "Santa Claus" brought Ralphie the BB gun]
I had one when I was eight years old.
What if he hurts himself?
[the Bumpus hounds break in the house and raid the kitchen]
Holy smokes, the turkey!
[the old man arrives too late to see that the dogs already devoured the turkey]
Oh, my... God! You sons of - !
[the dogs leave out the back door]

[shouts, high-pitched]
SONS OF BITCHES! BUMPUSES!
Hey Dad! I bet you never guess what I got you for Christmas!

[staring blissfully into space]
A new furnace?

[chuckling]
He he, that's a good one Dad!

[lauging]
He he he!
My old man was one of the most feared furnace fighters in Northern Indiana.
